metadata.synopsis: In this adaptation of John Berendt's book, a young journalist, John Kelso (John Cusack), travels to Savannah, Ga., to cover the city's Christmas celebration amid a backdrop of eccentric characters. He becomes intrigued by a sultry singer, Mandy (Alison Eastwood), and engrossed by a murder trial. Wealthy society figure Jim Williams (Kevin Spacey) is accused of shooting his male lover, and the question is whether it was in self-defense as he claims.

reviews: Crisp characterisations make Midnight a pleasant pastime, although when it's over, you're not really sure what it was all about.
The one crucial miscasting is Eastwood as director. He approaches the story like a tourist.
The picture has a smoky, laid-back style that suits it during quieter moments yet feels out of place when the piece's more spiritually tinged escapades are front and center.
Seems like alchemy in reverse - a golden property is turned into lead.
Spacey, the best reason to see Midnight, gives his usual suave, effortless performance.
I think Clint Eastwood's Midnight in the Garden of Good and Evil is a great movie.

[H]as a wonderful documentary feel to it: There is no score other than ambient music... and some of the dialog sounds almost improvised. The story unravels at its own slow, languid pace, which I found really drew me into its strange arena.
